title: Jordan Henderson and Declan Rice fail to ease Gareth Southgate's main England worry
text:

Gareth Southgate said he had to “accept responsibility” after an unbeaten qualifying run of 43 games was ended in England’s 2-1 loss to Czech Republic.

The Three Lions lost a European Championship or World Cup qualifier for the first time in 10 years in Prague, after debutant Zdenek Ondrasek came off the bench to net a late winner for the hosts.

Roy Keane was typically uncompromising in his analysis of England’s display, with the ex-Manchester United captain in the ITV studio declaring England “got what they deserved”.

That was a sentiment that Southgate agreed with, insisting: "We didn't play well enough, simple as that.”

But why didn't England play well enough?

(Image: PA)

In the cold light of day, Southgate made a number of decisions that simply didn’t work out, the biggest of which was changing formation and using Jordan Henderson and Declan Rice as a double pivot at the base of midfield.

Having brought Mason Mount into the starting XI at the expense of Ross Barkley, Southgate switched England from the 4-3-3 shape they have used since the 2018 World Cup back to a 4-2-3-1 - a formation last used in a drab 1-0 win over Slovenia, secured via a 94th minute Harry Kane winner, in 2017.

Certainly the change appeared to be a reaction to the side’s defensive struggles in the last qualifier against Kosov, when England won 5-3 but were unsteady defensively throughout, giving up a host of chances to the minnows.

Southgate's decision lasted just 45 minutes, after a first-half where England’s midfield struggled to gain a foothold in the game.

(Image: Michael Zemanek/BPI/REX)

Combined, Henderson and Rice made just 11 passes in the opening 20 minutes. Ahead of them, Mount, thriving at Chelsea and making his full debut, made just three.

That allowed the Czechs, who fell behind to Kane’s fifth minute penalty but equalised three minutes later, to take charge. Home goalkeeper Tomas Vaclik didn’t make a save until after the hour mark, but also the Czechs were, like Kosovo, too easily able to get at England’s defence.

(Image: PA)

Vladimir Darida, operating in a similar role to Mount, floated in behind the Rice/Henderson combination too easily and picked up possession far too often.

Patrick Schick, with just 27 minutes for RB Leipzig under his belt this term, similarly dropped off the front and picked up possession unchallenged too often, often down the inside right channel between Rice and Danny Rose.

"We tried something to make ourselves a bit more solid without the ball, and that didn't happen,” said Southgate. "We didn't look any more solid, and we were poor at using the ball in the first half."

Keane’s analysis of the England midfield was more fierce: "They’ve been really sloppy, Henderson and Rice – they might as well sit with us in the studio.”

(Image: REUTERS)

In the second period, with a switch to 4-3-3, pushing Henderson higher, there was greater balance. The best chance the Three Lions had, in the 57th minute when Raheem Sterling went clean through, came after Henderson received possession in the final third from a Sterling pass, laid off for Kane who found Sterling again with a third-man run.

"I think we were better in the second half and we created chances to win the game,” said Southgate.

That may have been true - they couldn’t have created less to be honest - but they still lacked real clarity and control. There were still too many nothing balls hooked aimlessly down the channel and no real combinations in the middle third to spring through the Czech's own pairing of Tomas Soucek and Alex Kral.

In terms of players, Southgate spoke post-game about having to select players "who are not playing well for their clubs”.

But certainly you couldn’t say that about Rice, one of West Ham’s better players again this season.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

However, on a night where England struggled, his limitations were exposed in terms of building play from deep and grabbing the game by the scruff of the neck. It’s easy to say with hindsight, but perhaps Harry Winks - the England midfielder with most passes in the Premier League this term (518) - would have been a smarter bet where getting on the ball and recycling possession is concerned.

Rice had just 44 touches and made only 36 passes of England’s 496 total passes. He also failed to make a single successful tackle before being hooked after the second Czech goal; in stark contrast, he averages 3.8 tackles and 2.3 interceptions per game for West Ham in the Premier League this season.

For the winning goal, Rice was largely culpable.

He reacted slowly to Darida's run into the penalty area, and as the Czech captain attacked the six-yard box, Michael Keane moved to cover and cut out the cross - leaving Ondrasek free on the penalty spot to score from the cut-back.

(Image: Wyscout SPA)

(Image: Wyscout SPA)

(Image: Wyscout SPA)

"It's clear we've got to improve without the ball, over a period of time," Southgate said. "That hasn't surprised us.

"It's something we've spoken about all week, and we didn't get the reaction that we needed today but it's not a time for me to look at individuals.

"I've got to make sure that we get the team back on track for Monday and pick the right team.”

Rice and Henderson are pillars around which Southgate will continue building as he looks towards Euro 2020.

However, as Southgate continues to seek answers with regards finding the right balance, Friday night’s experiment won’t likely be repeated.
description: England suffered a first defeat in a meaningful qualifier for 10 years with a 2-1 loss to Czech Republic
